title: The Problem with the Lore of League
body:
There’s never a time when someone isn’t voicing their concerns or complaints with the lore here on the SA&S boards.  As someone who consistently enjoys the lore updates I usually just dismiss these posts or try to argue with them, but after recent events I’ve started to formulate this half-baked theory.  I’m not an expert, nor am I a good writer, but here’s what I think. 

The largest problem with a storytelling format like League of Legends is the fact that every character has to (theoretically) be given the same amount of focus and all characters receive the same (gradual) treatment. 

In comic books a lot of villains have these wild outlandish plans, and you know more or less the hero will eventually save the day (in some cases). However the villains aren’t just villains, good comic book villains serve as foils and other literary devices to the heroes. 

Keep in mind that when I say “villains” and “heroes” I really mean “main character” and “side characters” 

Batman I would say has the most infamous rogues gallery, and over time his villains and his allies have grown as well, All of the robins have seen development as solo protagonists but at the end of the day it all comes back to Batman. 

League of Legends can’t really have a Batman so to speak, they have to give all 130+ champions an independent voice and perspective on the world.  

I think that’s why the Void and Shadow Isles champions tend to be the most consistently liked when it comes to lore.  You don’t really need an emotional arc or anything like that when you’re writing for Cho’Gath or Rek’Sai.  In fact Rek’Sai’s color story was told from another perspective entirely besides her own. 

Point is the more clear cut villainous champions of LoL usually have well recieved lore because they are the forever antagonists of League of Legends, people don’t root for them because they’re sympathetic or strike a chord, they root for them because they’re fucking badass bad guys. 

So when you have the rest of the cast as each being a sort of morally grey protagonist with their own depth and perspective you get a lot more arguments from people when it comes time for their lore to be revisited because their lore is much more vulnerable to the tiniest change in nuance spoiling all of it for some people. 

So with all these bios Riot is trying to turn some of the champions who may have been at first morally complex or sympathetic into more clear-cut visages of horror or might then people tend to get very miffed.

Anyway, just my little rant based on things I’ve observed.

I mean to be highly technical...everyone's the hero of their own story. And while I understand what you mean, and what it seems Rito is trying to do...I still like antihero and antivillain.

I feel characters like Viktor/Jayce could be foils. But Viktor at least original lore, wasn't a bad guy. And neither was Jayce even though lots of people died because of him.

You've really nailed it here... everyone is always the hero of their own story. No one should be portrayed as thinking "How evil can I be today? What nefarious deeds can I commit?" Otherwise, what you've got is a bland and tedious villain archetype, and not an antagonist. :-)

Speaking as a relative newbie to Riot and the LoL IP (I only started in January this year) I was actually amazed by how thin and inconsistent some of the older lore was. As has already been pointed out on this thread, there was a lot of designed-by-committee backstory for champions who probably wouldn't pass muster now, in the game. The thing I'm looking for, as Lead Narrative Editor, is story hooks we can pull out of old content, and develop into something new and interesting.

(And also, having stories that are ACTUAL stories, rather than just cool scenes!)

We have a lot of story content coming in the near future, and plans for grander, more ambitious stuff too. I hope you guys, having already shown an interest in this side of things, will stick around and let me/us know what you think as we get to it... :-)

And the biggest problem, going right back to the top of the conversation, is picking which characters to write about. We can't fit all 130+ champions into every story, and whichever ones we don't cover will be noticeable in their absence. Everyone is somebody's favourite!

So, an Amumu novel where he tries to make friends with Cho'Gath? Anyone? Anyone?

“Sion, beware of Ravens”

> She came to understand that the Demacian way was not the only way, able now to recognize its flaws as well as its boons.

I wonder how cool it would be to narrate her paradigm shift throughout her travels, maybe perhaps in conversation with characters from Noxus and Piltover. Especially Noxus, since she's grown up in a closed, isolationist kindgom and essentially encounters a functioning multicultural society for the first time. I wonder how she would reach to see mages revered and foreigners accepted. I wonder if she'll struggle to keep and open mind or if she'll struggle to stay loyal to her own kingdom -  or a bit of both, at different times.

Yes. That’s what an antihero is. A protagonist that does not conform to the normal precepts of being heroic. While still possessing a drive to make them the main character of their story. 

Xerath’s story is entirely focused on his actions and motivations while all other characters are described in relation to his desires and movements.  He also does not possess the standard characteristics of a hero: morality, empathy, and all of that. 

He’s pretty standard antihero really. 

Ain’t the terms fault it got coopted to start meaning “heroes who happen to be mean and/or bloodthirsty.”

There is a difference between Anti-hero and Villain protagonist.

Just being the protagonist doesn't automatically make you the hero.

Mate we are on the internet. You can just look up a term if you don’t know it. 

Here I will do it for you:

Antihero from Merriam Webster

>a protagonist or notable figure who is conspicuously lacking in heroic qualities. 

That’s it. 

Villain protagonists are, by definition a subset of antihero. 

Is Xerath a protagonist in his lore? Yes. 
Is he lacking in heroic qualities? Yes. 

Congrats. He’s an antihero.
So if I wrote a story with the joker as the protagonist, does it mean that the joker is an anti hero?

Within the context of that story, yes. 

You could maybe make a claim that within the context of the wider Batman lore he’s still the villain. But honestly I think that argument is kinda shaky.
